 - 95 - ANNEX6 ANNEX 6: LAND ACQUISITION AND RESETTLEMENT Overall Preparation of Resettlement Action Plans 1. Prior to appraisal, all project cities presented the Bank with resettlement plans for those project components requiring land acquisition. The appraisal mission requested additional information on certain aspects of the plans and that information, together with the original plans, provides the basis for appraisal of resettlement for the project components requiring resettlement. All project cities-Wuhan, Xiangfan, Yichang, and Huangshi- have such components, as do several of the enterprises proposed for support under the line of credit. 2. The resettlement plans for individual cities and enterprises share many features, due to the fact that all were developed within the same regulatory framework (described in Chapter 2 of China: Involuntary Resettlement, Report 11641-CHA). The Bank review of Chinese resettlement policy showed that basing compensation on collective land ownership (for rural communities) or enterprises (in urban areas) effectively protected the interests of all groups but the unregistered population (migrants who have not been given the right of permnanent abode). The preparation of resettlement plans in this project was done with special attention to possible impacts on members of the unregistered population. Several such people have been identified as affected by resettlement, and appropriate measures taken to indemnify them, as explained in the text. 3. In each city (including cities in which project-assisted enterprises are sited), the resettlement efforts will be executed by the city land administration bureau, or another government agency with special responsibility for resettlement. All project cities have large ongoing investment programs that involve substantial resettlement and the assigned agencies are therefore experienced in this work. The executing agencies are those typically used in resettlement work and acknowledged in the Bank's resettlement review to be well placed to execute the work. Each will be required to submit quarterly reports on their efforts under the Bank project. The project offices in each city, together with the provincial project office, shall be responsible for ongoing monitoring of the resettlement effort. In addition, an independent agency will be retained to evaluate resettlement performance at regular intervals during active resettlement and 12 months after the last resettlement occurs. 4. Project components are expected to acquire over 140 hectares (ha) in some 25 discrete sites. This will lead to the permanent relocation of 39 families and temporary relocation of 137 families. It will also cause some 996 people to be given new jobs on land within their current company on village, given jobs with new companies, or switch to new places of self-employment due to loss of cultivated land, fish ponds, or industrial or

In addition to the discussions with the provincial project office, preappraisal and appraisal missions conducted separate discussions and field trips among all subcomponents in order to understand the basic scope of and preparation for land acquisition and resettlement. These discussions included project affected people, to validate the findings of the consultants on the participation process. A brief summary follows of the major mission and consultant findings. The full resettlement plan, dated November 3, 1995, can be found in the project files. Wuhan Wastewater Component 6. The proposed wastewater component includes the construction or expansion of five treatment plants and seven pumping stations, together with approximately 90 km of wastewater conveyors. Sites are scattered around the city, with the largest sites on the agricultural margins of the urban area. The largest site (Longwanzui) requires acquisition of 32.6 ha and the pumping station sites the smallest at 0.2 ha each.  -105 - ANNEX7 ANNEX 7: ENVIRONMENTAL ASSESSMENT SUMMARY Background 1. In 1993 the Government of China and the World Bank agreed to prepare a possible loan for the improvement of the urban environment in four major cities in Hubei Province. lhe project would provide approximately $160 million to the municipalities of Wuhan, Xiangfan, Huangshi and Yichang for improvements in wastewater collection and disposal, nightsoil collection and disposal and urban solid waste collection and disposal. For the control of industrial pollution, some $30 million would be provided to control both water and air pollution in highly polluting industries. The project would be an important first effort to clean up urban lakes and rivers along the middle reaches of the Yangtze as well as to begin dealing with serious air pollution problems. 2. The lack of sound environmental management is now at a critical juncture in Hubei Province as the pace of industrial development continues. Routinely, both domestic and industrial liquid wastes are discharged into rivers, sewers and lakes untreated. Most of these water bodies have seriously deteriorated to Class III or IV over the past few years with several lakes such as East Lake in Wuhan becoming eutrophic and displaying algal blooms each summer. Biological diversity in these lakes is also narrowing with the succession of several species of carp and deposition of thick sludge layers on lake bottoms. Water supplies must be drawn from Class II reaches of the Yangtze away frorn urban centers. 3. In the realm of solid waste, little or no sanitary landfill practices are used. Most solid waste is simply dumped along the periphery of cities. There is no treatment of leachate that enters either surface waters or groundwater. Collection and transfer practices are generally good but disposal remains a serious issue since the price of land has risen sharply in urban areas. Modern landfill practices are therefore necessary in order to maximize use of scarce land areas set aside for disposal. Major investment in all four project cities for landfills, transfer stations and vehicles is therefore necessary. 4. The project consists of over two dozen components, all with separate EAs performed by local design and research institutes. Coordination of these studies was carried out by HUEPO and a final, overall project EA, dated May, 1995, was prepared by Chinese Research Academy of Environmental Sciences located in Beijing. Each of the component EAs was reviewed at a detailed level with the overall EA providing conclusions of each.
 -106 - ANNEX7 Basic Environmental Strategy 5. In the area of water quality, Hubei authorities have chosen to apply an interim environmental strategy that seeks to maximize the potential of the Yangtze River for self- purification in the short run because of its large flows (23,400 m3/sec). This strategy basically seeks to improve the quality of lakes and streams by diverting wastewater flows to the river via large collectors and outfalls. Prior to discharge into the Yangtze, pretreatment on primary treatment facilities are provided to remove solids and grit but not biological treatment is planned in the short term for economic reasons. Hubei authorities propose to go to primary and secondary treatment as additional financing becomes available and depending on the biological condition of the Yangtze River as these new waste flows are added. 6. Sound solid waste management in Hubei Province is severely limited by the scarcity of landfill capacity. Informal dumps exist at the periphery of most cities that need to be upgraded to sanitary landfills. The project will establish such landfills in each of the four cities as an pilot or demonstration so that other landfills can be developed by local authorities. The strategy is to develop these sites so that more refuse can be disposed of in the future as waste flows increase with population and general economic conditions. 7. The strategy associated with the industrial pollution control components is of reducing air pollution primarily and wastewater discharges secondarily. In project cities, up to 70 percent of wastewater effluents are from industry discharged into a combined sewer system or directly into lakes and rivers. The components were selected on the basis of continued financial viability of the enterprise and the seriousness of air and water pollution for which they are responsible. The relocation of two cement plant and the modemization of a steel mill will do much to reduce ambient air quality pollutants such as particulate and S02 in those respective cities. In addition, a pollution control fund will be established for small industries and the TVIEs, which contribute a great share of both water and air contaminants in the Province but which are difficult to control without such financial means. Review of Alternatives 87. In the selection of project components and sites, a complex process of review was undertaken. First, a long list of components were proposed by municipal officials with the aid of experts consultants. Some 68 components in the four project cities involving wastewater were initially proposed, of which seven were finally selected. Cleanup of East Lake in Wuhan was ranked as Number One because some 10 percent of the city's water supply comes from this highly polluted source. Once projects were selected, a review of alternatives required a least-cost approach, involving the least disruption, was proposed. 88. On the solid waste side, altematives involved a review of landfill sites and transfer station sites based on financial resources available. Other disposal methods such as incineration and composting were immediately rejected as being too uncertain in terms of reliability and high costs. The only reliable disposal option is sanitary landfilling but the question of picking a site can be complex. The sites selected (Jinkou in Wuhan for example) were either already being used as a landfill or a dump, or have been studied for some time by municipal authorities, design institutes and geotechnical consultants. 89. The selected sites have to have several attributes; cheap land and of sufficient scale; easily accessible for transport vehicles; away from communities; a stable and predictable hydrology; adorable geotechnical characteristics such as an impervious bottom layer; the availability of cover soil; and a suitable discharge point for the leachate. Each of the project cities had only three or four candidate sites and the most favorable was clearly evident. 90. The issue of wastewater collection coupled with pretreatment was one that required careful study. The concept as pointed out earlier was to clean up Yangtze tributaries and urban lakes to the detriment of the Yangtze River itself. Again, reasons for this included the massive scale of flow and the river's large assimilation capacity.

The planned research program includes four studies: (a) Survey of Township and Village Enterprise (TVE) Pollution Discharges: The TVE industrial sector in rural areas is a rapidly growing and increasingly important part of China's economy. In recent years in Hubei, water and air pollution from TVEs represented about 2.2 and 11.7 percent, respectively, of the province's total pollution discharges. Pollution from TVEs, while not large at this time, represents a growing problem in the province, because most have no pollution control systems. The proposed survey will assess all TVEs in Hubei. It will include assessment of the existing economic situation of each enterprise, production capacity, process technology, waste discharges, pollution control and management. Some limited data collection will take place where statistics are not already available. The future potential pollution from TVEs. Costs of treating emissions or substitution of cleaner technology will be determined and a time-kt und :mplementation program will be established. The Y 1.0 million survev is expected to start l!v tli end of 1996 and be completed by mid- 1 998.
 -134 - ANNEX II (b) Survey of Discharge Permit System Implementation: The pollution control discharge permit system, established in 1989, is being implemented in Hubei to reduce air and water pollution in the Province. To date, about 1,500 industries have applied for a permnit, but only 150 have been issued. The current implementation program calls for 95 percent of the industries to be issued permits by the year 2000. This study/program will serve to promote the pollution control permit system among industries in Hubei. It will stress the importance of its implementation and enforcement, and ensure the collection of the total levies determined to be assessable. The Y 500,000 survey is expected to commence in mid-1996 and is to be completed by mid-1997. (c) Study of Pollution Control of Fertilizer Industry in Hubei: There are about 64 nitrogenous and 40 phosphatic fertilizer plants of varying sizes in Hubei, producing about 900,000 and 550,000 tons, respectively, per year. Air pollution emissions from fertilizer plants represent about 25 percent of the total air pollution in urban areas. The proposed study will: (i) assess the existing production and water/air pollution situation for fertilizer plants in Hubei; (ii) determine the impact of anticipated future paper production capacity; (iii) determine pollution control and technology choice that will bring the industry into compliance with environmental standards; (iv) estimate the cost of the interventions and (v) set out a multiyear program to implement the proposed systems. Estimated cost of the study is Y 500,000. It is expected to commence by the end of 1996 and be completed by the end of 1997. (d) Study of Pollution Control of Pulp and Paper Industry in Hubei: There are 327 paper mills in lIubei, producing about 500,000 tons per year, which places Hubei thirteenth in production capacity in China. Only about 12 percent of the wastewater discharges is treated to standards, and the remainder is discharged, untreated, to watercourses. The proposed study will: (i) assess the existing production and water/air pollution situation for paper mills in Hubei; (ii) determine the impact of anticipated future paper production capacity; (iii) determine pollution control and technology choice that will bring the industry into compliance with environmental standards; (iv) estimate the cost of the interventions and (v) set out a multiyear program to implement the proposed systems. Estimated cost of the study is Y 600,000. It is expected to commence by mid- 1996 and be completed by mid- 1997. 5. The research program serves several purposes.  - 136- ANNEX 12 ANNEX 12: HUBEI ENVIRONMENTAL POLLUTION CONTROL FUND Introduction 1. China is taking a variety of measures to bring municipal and industrial pollution under control. One method, addressed to industries, is to create revolving loan funds at the provincial or municipal level that provide financing for the control of liquid, solid and gaseous wastes, particularly to those with the greatest environrnental impact. A regulatory framework wherein industries are required to meet specified waste discharge standards and an institutional structure to organize and operate the funds are prerequisite to their success. Almost 4,000 people are engaged in pollution control activities in the province. 2. In 1982, Chinese environmental law provided for the establishment of provincial. municipal, and county environmental funds financed by pollution fees. These originally provided subsidies and grants for pollution reduction investments in industrial and municipal pollution reduction projects, and for EPB environmental monitoring and enforcement. In 1988, an amendment allowed up to 30 percent of the fees to be loaned. rather than granted, to enterprises. Bank projects in Tianjin, Jiangsu, Liaoning and Zhejiang, and the Medium-Sized Cities project, have supported improved environmental fund project identification and management. Pollution Fee Collection and Use in Hubei Province 3. In Hubei, municipal and county EPBs collect pollution fees, while the provincial, municipal and county EPBs jointly plan fee collection and utilization. According to a fund allocation plan provided by the EPBs, the local finance bureaus issue orders and extend funds to subprovincial level PCBCs for loan disbursement. 4. Fees are assessed according to waste discharge information provided to levy offices by the local monitoring stations. On the average, large polluting industries should be monitored monthly. However, due to lack of monitoring resources, some industries receive their fee bill according to waste discharge load estimates by monitoring stations. In Hubei. the top individual polluters remain the steel industry, cement and chemicals. 5. Fee rates have been established for wastewater discharges, waste gas emissions, solid waste dumping and noise pollution. Between 1985 and 1993, total fee collection amounts to Y 583 million from 5,640 enterprises. Of the collected fees, about 71 percent were used for industrial pollution control, 4 percent for nonindustrial environmental improvement projects and 25 percent for EPBs' environmental monitoring and
 -137- ANNEX 12 eniorcement. During 1985 to 1993, about 7,800 industrial pollution control projects were supported by pollution fee funds, totaling about Y 1.2 billion, of which 24 percent came froii El'13 sources. In 1993 alone, some 209 pollution sources were treated. Pollution fees for indtustrial pollution control clearly played an important role in Hubei. 6. Bank Experience in China with Environmental Funds. The Bank has supported the establishment of environmental funds under five different projects and four of them have been in operation for at least one year. The Bank-assisted funds were found to have the following advantages over other funds: (a) they provide a stronger framework for management, including organization, staffing and operation regulations, and, indirectly, provide the basis for other environmental protection management measures including the permit system and the promotion of pollution prevention programs; (b) institute rigorous requirements and procedures for project preparation and appraisal ensuring a higher project success rate; and (c) provide training for capacity-building to staff of the fund offices in the technical and financial areas. 7. On the other hand, appraisal procedures have been expensive compared to the size of the typical loan, which has been under $1.0 million. Due regard needs to be given to modifications of the appraisal procedures to bring down costs while maintaining quality. The Hubei Environmental Pollution Control Fund (HEPCF) 8. The purpose of establishing HEPCF is to strengthen the existing Hubei pollution prevention program with a technically, institutionally and financially sustainable mechanism. The Fund would primarily assist small-scale industrial enterprises to control pollution through waste minimization measures, modifications or renovations to existing plants to reduce waste outputs or to recycle waste generated during production. Industrial upgrading projects designed to reduce the amount of pollutant discharge and to save natural resources and energy, commercial waste recovery services and centralized treatment plants would also be considered by the Fund. Some 300 small, polluting enterprises that have been identified as contributing significantly to the provincial pollution load will receive preferential access to HEPCF. 9. Organization and Financing of HEPCF. HEPCF would be a self accounting governrment entity. with initial capital equivalent of Y 87 million. The Bank Loan/ IDA Credit would provide $5.0 million and HEPB would contribute an equivalent sum from industrial pollution discharge fees (no less than Y 15.0 million for each of the first three years). While the size of the Bank/IDA contribution has been kept small ($5 million), the justification for Bank/IDA support for the fund derives from first, the advantages listed in paragraphi 6(a) above, second, the elevation of flubei's existing pollution prevention program into an internationally supported one, supplemented by focused training to further
 - 138- ANNEX 12 improve environmental management, and third, the confidence building and institutional strengthening expected to accrue to HEPB. 10. HPG has designated HEPB to administer HEPCF. HPG would appoint a steering committee which would oversee the preparation of an operational manual, setting out the criteria for subloans processing and approvals. The Steering Committee would propose policies for application for HEPCF funding, formulate rules and regulations for Fund management, select a depository agency for the Fund and define the terms and conditions for Fund loans. The HEPCF Steering Committee would also determine institutional structure and staff composition of the HEPCF Management Office and approve its annual work plan and budget. 11. The Fund Management Office (FMO) would have up to 12 staff, to be recruited over a three-year period, including specialists in environmental science and technology, industrial processing, economics and finance, and administration. The director would be appointed by the Steering Committee, and other staff would be locally recruited. The main role of FMO would be in investment project planning, coordination between borrower and agent bank, review of project feasibility and supervision of project implementation. Financial appraisal will be handled within FMO, while technical appraisal will rely on consultants for industry-specific expertise. 12. Project Selection. Each application would have to be reviewed by the local industrial bureau and planning commission, and approved by the concerned local Environmental Protection Bureau, to ensure consistency with municipal environmental planning. Based on the general project selection criteria mentioned above, a formula for ranking would be developed to prioritize submitted project proposals. Project Management Procedures 13. HEPCF operating procedures would be drafted and would be approved by the HEPCF Steering Committee. Fundamental project management procedures would be: (a) The Fund Management Office would issue HEPCF directives and solicitations for project proposals to the sublevel provincial environmental protection agencies and planning agencies; (b) With consent from the local industrial bureau, the enterprise would submit a loan application to the environmental protection agency and planning agency of its location; (c) The environmental protection agency and planning agency would review the application for consistency with local development and environmental plans; (d) The enterprise would prepare a feasibility study report, including a financial proposal for investment and an environmental impact assessment;
 -139- ANNEX12 (e) After the project has been appraised, FMO would submit the appraisal report to the World Bank Group for no-objection, along with proposed loan conditions. The Bank/IDA would provide ex-ante review of the first three subloan projects and thereafter each subloan of over $300,000, with all other subloans subject to ex-post review. (f) The HEPCFF Steering Committee would be responsible for the final approval of subloan projects. After approval, FMO would confirm the loan to the enterprise, any cofinancing agencies and the agent bank; (g) FMO would supervise the implementation of the project; (h) After satisfying itself as to the quality of a commissioned project, the relevant bureau would issue a Certificate of Examination and Acceptance to the enterprise; (i) The bureau in charge would submit examination and acceptance documents for the project to FMO; (j) FMO would separately assess whether the project meets the design document requirements. If it does not, FMO would arrange for appropriate departments to intervene, seeking necessary amendments to the project. Project Appraisal 14. For the technical appraisal of individual projects, the general criteria to be considered are: (a) the project's impact on the ambient environment; (b) investment and operating cost per unit pollution load reduction; (c) efforts made on pollution prevention; (d) compliance with environmental regulations and standards; and (e) technical feasibilitv and least-cost option. 15. The economic appraisal for investment of the individual enterprise must show the enterprise is economically viable. 16. For the financial appraisal of the subproject, each enterprise would have to show that it, as a whole, would be financially viable, including meeting a debt service ratio larger than 1.4. For joint waste treatment facilities, a financing plan for the operation and maintenance of the facility would be required. Project Financing Procedures Between Agent Bank and Borrower 17. The agent would be a bank acceptable to the World Bank. Once a subloan application is approved by HEPCF, the agent would execute the loan according to procedures described below:
 -140- ANNEX 12 (a) The agent would confirm the project financing plan with the borrower, in accordance with the loan agreement signed between HEPCF and the enterprise. (b) The project unit would open an account with the agent. (c) The agent would disburse funds upon receipt of a statement of expenditure, in the form of invoice or letter of credit. Normally, disbursement would be made once a month. (d) The agent would supervise the fund's use by the project unit. If project funds are found to have been used for any purpose other than the approved project, the agent would refuse further disbursement and notify the FMO. (e) The agent would report to HEPCF quarterly on the financial status of loans made to borrowers. The agent would also report emerging issues and make suggestions for improvement as needed. (f) At project completion the agent would finalize the financial accounting. (g) If projects fail to meet project date or design criteria, the agent shall notify FMO. (h) The agent would assist HEPCF in the collection of loan principal, interest, late payment penalties and fines. 18. Disbursement would be made through the agent from the special account for HEPCF in the Hubei Finance Bureau. The Fund would be audited annually, to include a management letter. Loans 19. The HEPCF loan for any project would be limited to 100 percent of foreign exchange costs, or 50 percent of total project costs (excluding land), whichever is higher. Total project size would normally not exceed $1 million. Loan maturity would be three to five years, with up to two years' grace. HEPCF would bear the subloan credit risk and the enterprise the foreign exchange risk. The subloan interest rate would be no less than the IBRD standard variable rate plus a spread of 1.5 percent, with a commitment charge of 0.75 percent. Repayments to HEPCF would be recycled for additional subprojects to the extent funds are not needed for repayment of the World Bank loan. HEPCF Project Pipeline 20. A tentative subloan project pipeline has been prepared by HEPB (see HUEPO Feasibility Study for details).
 -141- ANNEX 12 Institutional Development and Equipment Needs 21. The Fund Management Office personnel would undergo an extensive training program. Training courses would include economic and financial analysis, waste management, waste reduction technology, particularly resource recovery/recycling and clean technology. Training and equipment for HEPCF will be partially financed under Package C of the technical assistance schedule.

 -156- ANNEX 14 ANNEX 14: ECONOMIC, SOCIAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL CONSIDERATIONS A. PROJECT JUSTIFICATION 1. The Bank Group highlighted enhancing environmental protection and alleviating infrastructure bottlenecks as two of the four areas of concentration under the China Country A\ssistance Strategy (CAS) presented to the Board in June 1995. The Bank Group's close collaboration witlh the Chinese government covers both the regulatory and service provision aspects of urban environmental maniagement. The China. Environmental Strategy Paper sector study led to an Environmental 'Technical Assistance Project that assists NEPA in its ef'forts to find more efficient regulatory methods, improve staff capabilities, and bolster enivironimental monitoring. In addition to national regulatory assistance, the Bank Group is currently involved in tive urban environmental projects in eight cities, which incorporate policy, financing and organizational strategies for improved environmental regulation and service delivery at the provincial and municipal levels. Another four ongoing investment projects involving 12 cities include related issues such as municipal water supply and sanitation needs. The initial round of projects focused on China's largest cities-Shanghai. Beijing, and Tianjin-and those located primarily in the wealthier northeast and coastal provinces. Environmental pressures remain very high in those areas and cooperation will continue, as with the recently appraised Second Shanghai Sewerage Project and the Shiandong Environmenit Project IIow being prepared. However, the proposed Hubei Urban Environmental l'roject marks a shift in geographic focus, moving toward inland and poorer areas. I lubei, a mieedium-income province, is located in central China, wvhile projects now hbing prepared in thle very poor Yunnan and Guangxi provinces will further test the t'easibility of policy and institutional solutions. 2. 3Ban;kwide municipal management sector work (Urban Service Delivery: Finding the Right Incentives) emphasizes the need to properly assign functional responsibilities and link revenue to expenditures. In China's case, environmental services are appropriately provided at the municipal level, where a high percentage of government reventue is also captured. China: Urhan Environmental .Service Management concludes that the major failing in environmental services has been dependence on municipal budget transfers to fund services, while greater reliance on user charges would be af'fordable, induce resource conservation, and create a more dependable income stream. For that reason, increasing tariffs has been a major focal point of the policy dialogue in this project. This responds, too, to a major finding in the OED review of Bank water and sanitation projects (Water Supply and Sanitation Projects: The Bank Experience 1967- 1'089), wherein physical performance was generally good, but sustaining financial
 -157- ANNEX 14 viability and overall sectoral development was less successful. Adequate sector revenues have been so crucial to successful operation of these investments that the Bank now sees the needed tariff structures as the major sign of municipal commitment and therefore asks for initial adjustments to be made during project processing. The proposed project follows this model. 3. This project thus responds to Bank sector work and sector experience, and CAS objectives, first through an improved regulatory environment, reduction of current pollution loads, and protection of critical water and land resources and second through commercialization of operating agencies, and improved tariff policy and operating techniques. The Bank's strategy flows from and supports China's Environmental Action Plan and Agenda 21, which provide the basis for joint Government and Bank action in the environmental sector, especially in regard to the urban environment. Finally, the provincial focus recognizes the effective decentralization of regulatory and investment authority in China, and draws on local political power and commitment to induce wider use of the solutions demonstrated under the project. 4. The project supports provincial efforts to substantially reduce pollution within the province, especially within densely populated urban areas, by providing new models for the efficient organization and financing of urban environmental services and financing for wastewater and solid waste handing and treatment, and for industrial pollution control. Specifically, the project would support: (a) the more aggressive use of user fees to shift the burden of pollution abatement to the polluter and induce waste minimization and new organizational forms for wastewater providers, to allow improved management tools and to help minimize the cost of abatement; (b) the provincial and municipal EPBs in their efforts to implement more effective regulatory instruments; (c) expansion of sewerage services, hence a reduction in water pollution, within the boundaries of Wuhan, Xiangfan, and Huangshi, thus protecting the urban environment and the health of their people; (d) the first municipal solid waste landfills meeting national standards in the cities of Xiangfan and Yichang, and major capacity expansion in Huangshi and Wuhan, with consequent protection of local land and water resources and flaring of landfill methane to reduce greenhouse gas emissions; and (e) a line of credit to allow abatement of important industrial point sources of pollution affecting large urban populations and a pollution control revolving fund to provide a model for such funds.
 -158- ANNEX 14 B. ECONONlic ANALYSIS 5. From an economics perspective, project formulation-within the constraint of developing an urban environment project-presented the major analytical challenge of allocating investment support across a potentially wide array of cities and sectors. Ideally, that allocation would maximize net present value, fully incorporating environmental externalities, within the project area. Yet, current methodologies do not allow quick or inexpensive, yet high confidence. estimates of the impact of interventions across such a broad choice set. Instead, a different macro allocation criterion was used, based on the fact that what was known with high confidence was that current policy and institutional structures needed substantial change if sustainable environmental protection was to be aclieved. Policy problems included urbani environmental services priced too low to discourage waste generation or provide the financing needed to build, maintain, and operate services suclh as wastewater collection and treatment. Government bureaus providing the services lacked the financial tools to develop effective tariff strategies or the operating autonomny needed to encourage managerial iimovation. Gaps in environmental regulation Vwcr: allso apparent. Therefore, choices about participating sectors and cities were made vith a view toward maximizing the impact of policy aned inistitutional innovation within the province. Specific investment choices within sectors and cities responded to municipal government strategies to bring ambient environmental quality or service standards up to national guidelines. For the latter, analyvsis sought the least cost option for meeting the guidelines. The detailed calculations can be found in the project files. Highlights of the analysis are given below. C ity And Sector Choices 6. I lubei Province has developed environmental improvement plans with annual, five year, and ten year horizons. These plans include upgraded urban environmental services in all of flubei's 30 cities and a focus on the 117 most highly polluting enterprises, most of wvhich are within city administrative boundaries. In urban environmental services, the plans higlhlight the relative lack of sewerage services within urbani areas-household and industrial wastewater typically discharges to creeks, rivers, and lakes rather than to sewer systems-and the virtual absence of sanitary landfills or other safe disposal for solid waste and nightsoil. Enterprise pollution abatement strategies locus on process change, siometimes accompanied by physical relocation of the enterprise. 7. In urban environmental service provision, cities were included in the project based on the size of the population potentially benefiting from improved services and considering their value as models to other provincial cities. After reviewing potential investments in some nine provincial cities, the four largest cities were selected for further project development. Each of those cities had already prepared environmental improvement plans that outlined priority service improvements, both in terms of the type of service and areas of the city needing service. With the project, each city established a council headed by a vice- mayor, with members from the environmental protection, urban services, plamning, and financial bureaus, to review existing plans and guide any decisions needed on scope or
 - 159 - ANNEX 14 administrative arrangements. Work with Bank missions colnfirmed the choice to extend sewerage systems and build or substantially expand sanitary landfills. 8. The Hubei strategy for industrial pollution control builds on national and provincial emissions control law and regulations. However, the current concentration-based emissions controls can produce the perverse results that even if all enterprises comply, high ambient pollution levels can result where receiving body volume is low compared to effluent volumes, or, when receiving body volumes and other characteristics create very high assimilative capacity compared to loads, enterprises will spend an excessive amount on pollution control. In response, the province is moving to a mass-based permit system, the implementation of which is an element of the Environmental Improvement Action Plan in this project. 9. For enterprises built before polluting effluents were regulated, cash flow alone rarely meets the financing needs of process changes or end-of-pipe treatment that will allow compliance with current effluent standards. Pollution abatement investments must compete in China's plan-driven credit market with investments typically offering much higher financial returns to sponsors. Where banks are able to make loans outside of state- dictated credit plans, they seek high and rapid returli opportunities, a feature uncharacteristic of pollution-abatement investments. Credit market constraints [described much more fully in the China Department's 1995 Capital Markets Sector Study (No. 14501-CHA)] do leave a large number of abatement opportunities in economically and financially viable enterprises that currently have a high pollution impact on large populations. Hubei Province therefore sought to use part of the loan to fund such investments. The Province agreed with the Bank on a selection process to identify enterprise pollution abatement programs that would have a high positive impact on urban populations and provide them access to a line-of-credit to finance the interventions. This line-of-credit activity is discussed more fully below. 10. The potential Bank loan for the municipal service and enterprise pollution control activities was far below the absorptive capacity of the province. Either urban environmental services or the industrial pollution control component could have absorbed the entire loan earmnarked for the province bv the State Planning Commission. Given that urban environmental problems could be successfully addressed only by a combination of urban servize and industrial pollution control measures, and that the high visibility of Bank- financed operations was thought important to providing model approaches to outstanding prob:ems, the HPG and Bank agreed that both types of activities should be incorporated into :he loan. The allocation of the loan between the two types of activities, approximately two ihirds to municipal services and one third to industrial pollution control, resulted from a shared judgment about the balance that would produce maximum impact within the province. Decisions about resource allocation within sectors and cities are detailed below:
 -160 - ANNEX 14 Wastewater Collection and Treatment 11. Wuhan. Currently, some 60 percent of the 1.8 million m3 average daily wastewater flows within the city of Wuhan discharge to sewers. In Wuchang district, a wastewater treatment plant with 50,000 m3 daily capacity was recently commissioned, but a lack of operating funds idles the plant for several months each year. Unsewered wastewater discharges to lakes, canals, and rivers within the municipality, all of which eventually discharge to the Yangtze. The quality of these surface waters has deteriorated rapidly in recent years, with that in the largest lake, East Lake (see Map 27250), now Class IV' in many areas and experiencing heavy eutrophication, Moshui Lake well below Class V, Nanhu Lake with BOD5 and cyanide over Class V standard and Nantaizi Lake plagued by eutrophication. Most smaller canals and rivers fail to meet Class V, although the Fu river does meet Class IV. Nonetheless, East Lake has been a major raw water source for domestic use in Wuchang district, with installed capacity equal to 10 percent of all Wuhan municipal supply, and its waters are used for irrigation, commercial and recreational fishing, other recreation, and industrial supply. Nanhu Lake serves the same functions with the exception of domestic potable water supply. Moshui has been lost to use except as a waste sink. 12. The Yangtze and Han Rivers split Wuhan into three large districts, all of which lack adequate sewering and wastewater treatment. To facilitate the introduction of institutional and tariff reforms throughout the city, the Wuhan municipal government sought to include Bank-supported work in each of the three districts. Investment priority, based on anticipated impact on water quality and the associated population, was first diversion of wastewater from East Lake in the Wuchang district; second capture of flows in west Hankou district, with discharge to the Fu River; and third, diversion of wastewater from Nantaizi Lake and Moshui Lake in Hanyang district, with preliminary treatment and discharge to the Yangtze. 13. Direct economic losses to East Lake pollution include those of water supply losses (averaging an additional Y 20 million/year as the cost of replacing East Lake supply with that from the Yangtze), additional health costs and lost recreational and development potential. The latter two costs are more difficult to evaluate than additional water supply costs, but Wuhan research institutes have attached estimated values of Y 21 million and Y 12 million annually to these losses. At a 12 percent discount rate, that represents a net present value of Y 401 million to the pollution damage, assuming that the worsening water quality would not cause further real increases in costs. The cheapest remedy for these losses would be to capture the wastewater flows and discharge them without treatment to the Yangtze, with its higher assimilative capacity. Investment costs for this approach would total about Y 300 million. However, such discharges to the Yangtze are no longer The water quality classification system: Classes I and I: high quality suitable for drinking water source; Class Ill: usable for drinking water after treatment; Class IV: boating, fishing, industrial water supply; Class V: irrigation and industrial cooling.
 -161- ANNEX14 permitted by the central govermment, in an attempt to preserve Yangtze quality at its current Class II level. The alternative selected, of expanding existing tertiary and secondary sewers on the western side of East Lake (see Map 27250) and expanding the existing wastewater treatment plant at Shahu, would permit primary treatment of up to 230,000 rn3/day of wastewater diverted from East Lake. An additional 150,000 m3/day of wastewater would be picked up on the south side of East Lake for discharge to South Lake after primary treatment. At an investment cost of approximately Y 640 million, these two interventions would divert and treat nearly all sewage flowing into East Lake and lead to the following estimated change in East Lake quality over time: Table 1: EAST LAKE PHOSPHORUS CONCENTRATIONS Time (years) 1 3 5 10 Total Phosphorus 60 32 26 24 (mg/m 3) 14. This would, for this indicator, improve water quality from Class IV to Class II. These estimates assume the inflow of Yangtze River water needed to maintain the water balance of East Lake, works for which would be included under the proposed project. Even with the wastewater flow abated, total phosphorus levels remain high because of phosphorus release from lake sediments. This problem is even more severe in other lakes and marks the difficulty of finding short-run solutions to water quality problems. The option of dredging the lake to remove polluted sediments was rejected as less effective than further extensions of the sewerage network. 15. An interceptor sewer would pick up 70 percent of sewage currently discharging to Moshui Lake, with high quality water flows from the Han River providing water balance. As noted above, Moshui serves solely as a waste sink at this point and no estimate has been made of foregone services compared to a lake in this location with usable water quality. Even with the planned diversion, given the very high pollutant loads in Moshui Lake sediments, water quality recovery is expected to take more than the 10 years needed by East Lake. Nonetheless, that recovery can be expected to bring the lake within Class V quality within a decade. The least cost approach relies on an open settling basin, rather than conventional treatment, to provide some solids removal prior to discharge to the Yangtze. 16. The densely populated West Hankou area currently discharges wastewater through open channels carrying combined stormwater and wastewater flows that eventually enter the Fu River. That river currently rates as Class IV or V, depending on measurement site. The existing open channels lack sufficient capacity for the growing wastewater volume, and overflow into streets, fish ponds and agricultural land is common. The city plan is to upgrade collection, providing the needed capacity to avoid overflows and, where possible, fully enclosing the sewers. Discharge would continue to the Fu River, after preliminary treatment. No quality improvement in that river would be possible until the addition of further treatment, which is contemplated after the year 2000. The least cost solution sought
 -162- ANNEX 14 to maximize capture of flows currently discharging to open channels within the overall budget constraint on this component. 17. Xiangfan. Currently, Xiangfan city wastewater flows discharge through tertiary and some secondary sewers to the nearest river or, in the Xiangcheng district, the city moat. As a result, those surface waters are highly polluted, with the smaller rivers such as the Qilihe and Xiaoqinghe failing to reach Class V water quality, the lowest permissible for any human use. Nonetheless, the water is used for irrigation, some is extracted for industrial use, and human contact continues through uses such as fishing. A large number of discharges go directly to the Han River, generally downstream of the municipal and industrial raw water irntakes. Despite the high assimilative capacity of the Han, that river falls from the Class I to Class II range above the city to Class III or IV below the city. The Han stands to lose a third of its flow to the South-North water transfer project over the next decade, and as it serves as a key raw water source down to Wuhan, the quality of its water is a particular concern for the province. As the main upstream city, Xiangfan is under pressure to minimize polluting inputs to the river. 18. Xiangfan has designed a collection and treatment system for its wastewaters, but has lacked adequate financing to install the system. After a review of the Xiangfan design and assessment of costs and counterpart funding ability, it was clear that even with Bank support the entire system could not be constructed within the time frame of this project. Based on Xiangfan's counterpart funding ability, and sizing for year 2010 flows, the physical scope of the project was determined by working upstream from the proposed treatment plant site. Treatment was set at the preliminary level after an assimilative capacity study showed that the 6.9 m3/sec municipal flows could continue to be discharged directly to the Han with no net deterioration of Han quality. The new outfall will have better dispersion characteristics than the current riverbank discharges. In anticipation of later need, the preliminary treatment works are being designed and sufficient land is being set aside for the addition of primary and secondary treatment as soon as that is feasible. Because serving either the Xiangcheng or Fancheng districts required major river crossings, only one could be supported under the project. The Fancheng crossing was substantially less costly and the district has the larger wastewater flows, so the lowest cost per cubic meter intercepted could be realized there. Conveyors of appropriate size were extended up through the Fancheng catchment until funds ran out. This permitted most discharges to the Xiaoqinghe and Qilihe, the largest rivers within Fancheng district, to be picked up. The quality of those rivers should rise from below grade to approximately Class 111. It also permitted interception of nearly all Fancheng neighborhood discharges to the Han, but here the pollution impact was simply displaced downstream. Design and construction work on further extensions of the system will be financed if the first phase realizes significant savings compared to estimated construction costs. 19. Huangshi. Wastes Disposal 22. Of the four project cities, only Wuhan and Huangshi have sanitary landfills or other means of preventing solid waste from becoming a long term environmental threat. The Wuhan site handles less than 25 percent of the city's municipal solid waste, and the Huangshi site takes about one third of that city's municipal solid waste. The remaining wastes go to either municipal dumps that, while well managed, lack any provision for leachate or gas control, or to informal dumps that lack the management of the municipal dumps. The other cities rely on a combination of municipal and informal dumps. Based on international experience, dumps without leachate or gas control pose a long run threat to the aquifers that run under them, to watercourses that receive leachate from them, and to
 -164 - ANNEX 14 surrounding land. If landfill gasses are not collected and flared, they contribute substantial amiounits of methane to the atmosphere. For these reasons, China has joined many other countries in stipulating minimum standards for leachate and gas control in landfilling of municipal solid waste. 23 *. Potential solid waste disposal strategies include recycling, composting, incineration, and landfilling. Recycling plays an active role in each of the cities, capturing most of the 5 percent of the municipal waste stream that can be profitably recycled. The industry is highly competitive, withl little scope for additional useful municipal intervention. Composting, to recycle organic materials, has been tested with scant success in Wuhan and other Chinese cities. Costs have been high and markets have not supported product sales. A major problem for composting and incineration is that over half of the waste stream is inorganic, with coal ash the dominant inorganic component. Analysis in other Chinese cities with similar waste streams has shown incineration to be substantially more costly than landfill. Based on that work, each of the four cities hias elected to use landfilling to handle their municipal solid wastes. 24. Eaclh of the project cities faces the need to build new sites, as current sites are approaching capacity. Cities have accepted that new solid waste disposal sites must comply with national standards, so have made no attempt to undertake the very difficult comparison of the cost of adding leachate and gas collection with the damage that would ensue from their absence. Damage estimates would depend on leachate diffusion through aquifers, systematic sampling of local water bodies to identify leachate impacts, then estimation of economic uses of those waters over time and the cost of forgone use or pollution amelioration. Gas emission volumes and dispersion would be easier to estimate, but damage valuation would be very uncertain. Given the long run risks inherent in unprotected landfills, the Bank accepted the municipal judgment on the need to provide leachate and gas collection and treatment without additional impact evaluation. 25. Once the decision was made on landfill standards, each city faced the need to identify the least cost site and design. Wuhan, Xiangfan, Yichang, and Huangslhi each considered a number of alternative locations, with one of the main decision criteria being to minimize the joint cost of transport, land acquisition and site development. As land acquisition cost correlates very strongly with resettlement impact, this criteria also minimizes resettlement. Yichang identified two potential sites with similar haul distances and resettlement impact. The site chosen was preferred because the other site was in a new industrial development zone and thought to be an inappropriate use of land in such a zone. Huangshi narrowed its choices to three sites, with the Xisai site preferred for easy access and minimum impact on surrounding populations. Wuhan had an existing site with suitable land available for expansion. To take advantage of existing infrastructure, no other sites were considered. Detailed assessment of the choices by each city is described in the project files. Xiangfan has two possible sites that appear to have similar unit costs. Detailed analysis has been completed on one site and continues on the other.
 -165- ANNEX 14 Industrial Pollution Control 26. The industrial pollution control component has two subcomponents, one a line of credit for major investments and the other a pollution control fund targeting small investments and small-scale enterprises. Eligibility for the line of credit was restricted in the first instance to Hubei's 117 most polluting industrial enterprises, which are responsible for over 60 percent of industrial pollution in Hubei. The toxicity of enterprises' pollutants and the population affected by the pollution were evaluated. The higlhest-imiipact firms were then subject to a simple economic screening that eliminated (a) all enterprises which had a negative net worth and were losing money, and (b) any enterprise whose abatement strategy depended on production of a commodity in which the enterprise had no prior experience. With priority based on their environmental impact, remaining firms were then eligible for more thorough technical, financial, and economic appraisal. The funds available for subloans would finance pollution control programs for approximately six firms, if current investment plans remain unchanged after appraisal. One appraisal of Ezhou Iron & Steel (Egang) was successfully undertaken during overall project appraisal, to test the quality of local appraisal efforts. The remainder will be done in the early months of project effectiveness. 27. Technical appraisal will focus on feasibility and efficiency: is operation of the proposed investment within the technical capabilities of the firm, and will it result in production clean enough to meet national and local discharge standards while yielding a significant improvement in ambient air or water quality for a significant population. The economic appraisal will look at whether the technical choice was the most economically efficient among technical alternatives and whether the input and output market prospects support the sustainability of the financial appraisal results. The financial appraisal will focus on the company as a whole, rather than on the particular technology. This is because the most effective intervention may be end-of-pipe treatment of an effluent stream, with no financial return other than cessation of effluent fees. 28. The successful appraisal covered two investments at the enterprise ranked as most environmentally damaging among viable firms. Details of the appraisal may be found in the Project Files. The key appraisal finding showed the firm to be financially healthy and economically viable. The firm benefited from progressive price liberalization after 1992, and in 1994 had net profits of Y 220 million on sales of Y 1,520 million and low debt compared to the industry average. The latter finding was particularly important given the rapid integration of China's steel industry into the international market economy. In brief, the first Egang investment will replace a 40-year old electric arc furnace that is responsible for 23 percent of the TSP concentrations within an urban area containing some 200,000 people. The proposed investment is in a new furnace, incorporating up-to-date air pollution control, which will produce virtually no particulates or NO, and will improve air quality for affected people from Class III to Class IL. The new furnace will have higher capacity than the old one and will also use less electricity per ton of steel produced. TFlc investment will yield an estimated 12 percent financial and 23 percent economic rate ot return on the investment, where the economic rate of return incorporates none of die air
 -166- ANNEX 14 quality gains. Most of the gap between the financial and economic rates of return is due to the fact that Egang steel is priced 20 to 30 percent below CIF imported prices for equivalent products. That gap leaves substantial room to absorb price pressures should the world steel market soften. Table 3 summarizes the economic return calculation.
