The four factors judged to have the greatest impact on the economic rate of return were changes in the economic price of steel, an increase in input costs relative to sales prices, higher-than-anticipated capital costs, and lower-than-anticipated efficiency levels. Egang steel prices are already over 20 percent below border prices for the product and a further 10 percent price drop would drop the ERR by 3 percent. An increase in input costs would have relatively little impact on the ERR because it would have a nearly equal impact on the without-project scenario, where steel production continues with the current furnace-a 10 percent cost increase would drop the ERR by only I percent. The ERR is also relatively insensitive to capital cost increases, with a 2 percent drop for a 10 percent capital cost increase. A further factor considered was a "learning curve" in using the new fumace, whereby operating efficiency would be below the norm for, say, the first three years of operation. Given the large staff of engineers and operators experienced with electric-arc furnaces, three years is seen as an outer bound for those efficiency losses. Of these various factors, the risk of "learning curve" inefficiencies and steel price decreases are judged most likely (although vis-a-vis the international market, upside price potential would appear to outweigh downside). To drop the ERR to the test level of 12 percent, a combination of factors including a 20 percent drop in sales price (to over 40 percent below international market levels), a I0 percent increase in capital costs, and a 10 percent "learning curve" drop in efficiency would have to occur. This or similar adverse combinations are judged highly unlikely given Egang's operating experience and recent market history in the key input and output markets.
 -167- ANNEX 14 30. The high and robust economic returns to the proposed air pollution control investment are an example of a "win-win" solution to an environmental problem. However, Egang also includes an example of damaging wastewater discharges that are difficult to value, and the main available intervention increases operating costs with no corresponding increase in a marketable product. Egang discharges some 17 tons a year of phenol, 11.8 tons of cyanide, and 462 tons of oil, as well as substantial solids and COD into local watercourses and then the Yangtze. The phenol and cyanide are over 90 percent of all such discharges in Ezhou city and the oil 63 percent, with the result that the major urban waterways fall to category IV for phenol and oil, and II for cyanide. 31. To reduce these discharges, Egang will substantially revamp their wastewater handling system. All discharges currently entering the Yanglan Lake or Xingang River will be intercepted, treated, and reused, ending Egang's contribution to their pollution. Yanglan Lake is fished and used as an industrial water supply source. Xingang stream provides potable water for villagers and a source of industrial water supply. No epidemiological work has been done on the impact of Egang discharges through fish consumption or domestic water supply, so damage estimates were not possible. The most serious discharges, from the coking plant, will continue to discharge directly to the Yangtze. However, a new coking wastewater treatment plant financed by the project will radically reduce pollutants in that discharge, with, for example, phenol falling from 1.53 tons/year to 0.45 tons/year and oil from 32.4 tons/year to 6.5 tons/year. The net effect of the investment will be to bring the Xingang River and Yuanlan Lake to Class II in tllese pollutants, allowing safe use of the water. The cost is high-an estimated Y 130 million or $13 million. 32. Based on the industrial pollution control ranking system, investments in Egang are anticipated to have the most substantial positive environmental impacts. The remaining top-ranked firms on the short list are two cement plants, wastewater and waste gas treatment at two chemical plants and wastewater treatment at a pharmaceutical plant. 33. The environmental pollution control fund remains to be established, so cannot be assessed in the same way the line-of-credit can be. The goal of the fund differs from the line of credit, in that it strives to serve as a model for the operation of the municipal and county run pollution control funds capitalized through pollution levy fees. These are revolving funds, but to date have lacked effective management, targeting, and credit policies. Hence, while the appraisal goals are similar to the line of credit, the target firms and pollution problems are much smaller scale. The fund will seek to minimize management costs, while effectively recycling loans. The fund will bear credit risk, for, like the line of credit, banks will play a solely agent role. Again, like the line of credit, loans will be made at a rate at least 150 basis points above the Bank variable rate, the margin to be determined by operating costs and credit risk assessment. However, the fund will not have the direct power of the finance bureau to encourage timely loan servicing by enterprises. Also, it will face a history of disbursement of pollution levy fees as grants. The fund will respond to these risks in two ways. First, by careful financial analysis and
 -168- ANNEX 14 conservative lending and second by concentrating on smaller loans with relatively short repayment periods. C. ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT 34. The project would contribute significantly to improving Hubei's environment, in ways detailed in the body of the SAR and the annexes. Potential adverse impacts from the sanitary landfill and industrial pollution control components require an "A" category in terms of the World Bank's Operational Directive on Environmental Assessment (EA). Accordingly, a full EA has been completed, reviewed by the Bank and approved by NEPA. The full report can be found in the project files. Annex 8 details the EA findings and reflects the findings of the appraisal mission. The resettlement impact of the project will be managed through a resettlement action plan that can be found in the project files and is summarized in Annex 7. D. AFFORDABILITY AND POVERTY ASSESSMENT 35. The affordability issue arises only with the wastewater components of the proposed project. The industrial pollution interventions will proceed only if the enterprise can demonstrate that it will remain financially sound after the investment, and solid waste charges will rise only for industrial and commercial users of the new landfills. Affordability of the new wastewater systems was tested against current consumption pattems and average income of the poorest 10 percent of the urban population in the three cities. The proposed first year tariff would consume an average of 0.25 percent of the income of the poorest 10 percent, based on 80 percent of water used. Indeed, because the poor are less likely than other households to have water piped to the house (using standpipes instead, for which no fees are currently charged), even the 0.25 percent figure represents an upper bound. 36. The affordability of the higher tariffs anticipated in later years will clearly depend on changes in real income among the urban poor over time. In real terms, the tariffs will increase to as much as twice the anticipated 1996 rate. With no change in real income and no consumption effect, the average wastewater bill would increase to 0.50 percent of average income for the poorest 10 percent of households. However, over the past decade, the real incomes of the urban poor have risen in line with overall income increases. If that pattem, and overall real personal income growth, continues near current rates, wastewater tariffs as a percentage of personal income would remain virtually unchanged from the first year level. In absolute terms, the increase would be fully offset by first year income gains. E. PROJECT RisKs 37. The proposed project faces or mitigates a variety of risks. Those risks are here grouped under three general headings: implementation and operational risks, regulatory risk, and risks to long term sustainability. Each type of risk will be discussed in turn.
 -169- ANNEX 14 Implementation and Operation Risks 38. These risks include a variety of institutional, physical, and financial factors that could interfere with the timely construction or operation of any of the project elements, or with the implementation of the institutional innovations. Specifically, these include: Municipal Components 39. Procurement Risks: Lack of familiarity with Bank procurement procedures and policies may lead to delayed procurement. Experience in a wide array of Bank projects has shown this risk to be substantial among new borrowers. HUEPO's use of an experienced Chinese tendering company (already engaged) will help mitigate the risk in preparing commercial documents. The plan to use international consultants experienced with Bankl financed projects to provide advisory services on preparation of technical documents. HUEPO will sign a contract for the latter services by negotiations and the consultant team will be in place well before effectiveness. 40. Financial Risks: These risks are of two sorts, those of counterpart funding and operational funding. Counterpart funding risks derive from the fact that the Bank loan covers only part of the construction costs. The wastewater agencies are financing a relatively small proportion of the investment out of current income, and that income depends on implementation of the new tariffs (discussed further under policy risk). Given the inelastic demand for water in the three cities (on consumption of which the wastewater charges are based), the conservative billing assumptions used, and the fact that the initial tariff increase will be implemented before project effectiveness, the risk of inadequate wastewater company revenues is deemed to be low. The bulk of the counterpart funds are allocated from the municipal budget. Indeed, to minimize risks in this area, municipal budgets were analyzed under the assumption that all counterpart funding would come from that source. Those budgets have been analyzed under growth assumptions that are conservative compared to recent experience. Even then, counterpart funding requirements would amount to less than 3 percent of on-budget revenues and no more than 40 percent of recent on-budget capital investment allocations in all but Xiangfan. Given the importance of off-budget revenues to cities (up to half of total revenue), both of those indicators suggest a higher exposure than actually exists. 41. Xiangfan's investment program would demand up to 4 percent of annual total on- budget expenditures and would represent, in the peak year, a doubling of the historical on- budget capital expenditures. Again, given the growing importance of off-budget income and investment, these figures overstate project exposure in Xiangfan. As with all the project cities, Xiangfan has identified and committed to specific funding sources for this project. Furthermore, the Bank sought independent analysis from the provincial finance bureau of the availability of and risks to the stated funding sources. Based on the Bank and provincial finance bureau assessments, the Xiangfan investment program was pared down to its current level, as representing a feasible investment under the conservative growth assumptions. Nonetheless, a substantial slowdown in municipal revenue growth, which
 -170 - ANNEX 14 would likely accompany any major downturn in the national economic cycle, would force the city to cut back on ongoing investments. Under similar circumstances, local governments in other Bank-supported projects in China have sometimes reduced their annual counterpart funding, lengthening the construction period. In Xiangfan's case, counterpart funding risks are minimized during the first year of implementation by the fact that the appraisal of the Xiangfan solid waste component has been delayed (for technical reasons unrelated to financing). This will allow overall progress in the first year of project implementation to be evaluated before committing to the additional landfill investment. 42. In terms of operational funding, Hubei province and the cities have agreed to a financial covenant that will, for wastewater operations, generate sufficient revenues through operations to meet anticipated operational, depreciation, and loan repayment needs. Initial tariff adjustments prior to project effectiveness, in addition, allow a contribution to capital. Solid waste operations will continue to rely on direct government allocations for a part of their operating costs, given the difficulty of billing households on a waste volume basis (per capita or per household taxes substitute for this). However, the ability fully to cost and charge for the important commercial and industrial services will increase revenues to the environmental sanitation bureaus, reducing dependence on the city and the risk of inadequate operating funds. 43. Construction Risk: The proposed investments differ little in construction demands from other work already successfully undertaken in the cities themselves, or elsewhere in the province. The one possible exception to this would come if the landfill in Yichang is deemed to need an artificial liner. Such liners have been rarely used in China and need particular care during installation and operation. To minimize this risk, the installation contract will require firms to demonstrate successful experience in the field. 44. Operational Risk: This risk is deemed to be very small due to the fact that all of the proposed technologies are in successful operation either in the cities themselves, or in other Chinese cities or plants with staff of equivalent background and training. The technical assistance planned under the project would further mitigate this risk by providing operational training on all newly constructed municipal facilities. 45. The shift to new organizational forms for wastewater management is critical to project success. All cities are well along in the process, with Xiangfan having successfully completed the transformation to an enterprise. In Huangshi, assets have been revalued and that work is being reviewed by the State Asset Bureau, the last step before formal transfer. Wuhan has begun revaluing assets and expects to undertake the transfer by the end of 1995, well before planned effectiveness. The groundwork is thus laid for introduction of the new accounting and management information systems needed to efficiently guide the work of these enterprises. In the long run, efficient operation will also depend on cities honoring the autonomy of the enterprises in personnel and other management decisions. This element of risk cannot be divorced from larger efforts within the economy to reforrn government relations with the state owned enterprise
 -171- ANNEX 14 sector. These issues have recently received thorough analysis in State Owned Enterprise Reform (currently in yellow cover). The solid waste sector presents a rather different challenge, as this will continue in bureau form. Here, the challenge is to introduce the new accounting tools. The risk to this is minimized by the advantage to the ESB of being able to identify costs and thus justify the tariffs agreed to by the cities. Industrial pollution control component 46. Two main types of risk to the industrial pollution control component will be addressed here. These are credit risk and the risk that the pollution abatement goals are not met. 47. Credit risk under the project is borne by the provincial government. Under the line of credit, the agent bank, for a fee, undertakes project appraisal and handles fund administration on behalf of the provincial government. An essential element of the project appraisal, which is subject to review and confirmation by the provincial finance bureau, is analysis of the firm's financial strength and the risk it faces in its input and output markets. The firm must meet a 1.4 debt service coverage requirement over the project life, providing that margin of safety to the government exposure. Representatives of the provincial finance bureau have stated that their subjective estimate of the credit risk in the project approaches zero. They argue that within the Chinese system as currently structured, the finance bureau has sufficient discretionary power over the state owned enterprises seeking access to the line of credit that they have primacy over all other creditors. Nonetheless, the loans are being made at no less than 150 basis points over the Bank variable lending rate, in US dollars, with the enterprise bearing the foreign exchange risk. With fees to the agent Bank amounting to no more than 50 basis points, the provincial government will capture at least 100 basis points to cover their costs and risks. In addition, they will enjoy the use of loan and interest payments in the interval between collection from the enterprise and repayment to the Ministry of Finance. 48. Given the well-known failure of many enterprises to operate their pollution abatement facilities, the analysis addressed the risk that pollution abatement goals would not be met. Based on the short-listed project designs, this risk is deemed to be very small. The reason is that, although not a requirement for access to the line-of-credit, the bulk of the proposed investments are in process changes. The pollution abatement in these investments derives not from add-on equipment, but from the intrinsic properties of the production process compared to the original. Thus, the proposed electric arc furnace for Egang does not have a "dirty" operating mode that could be used to save power or other inputs. Nor do the proposed kilns in the cement plants. An exception to this pattern can be found in the wastewater treatment plans for Egang. Here, one part of the strategy involves treating and reusing the cleanest part of the wastewater stream, and the reuse demand will help ensure adequate treatment. But the coke oven wastewater will, after treatment, discharge as before to the Yangtze. If the treatment plant were to shut down, enterprise operation would be cheaper but not otherwise affected. The only way to mitigate this risk is aggressive monitoring and application of heavy fines for violations.
 -172 - ANNEX 14 The local EPB does not have a history of such an approach, but has indicated that because the EPB system helped Egang gain access to the line of credit, Egang now has a moral obligation to operate the equipment, an obligation that did not previously exist. Moreover, the EPB system is more generally stepping up its pollution levy fee collections and pollution licensing system. so the new equipment will come on line in an era of increased attention to compliance. Policy/Regulatory Risk 49. Major policy risks include: (a) possible resistance to timely implementation of the new tarif'f structure and (b) that the sustained investment program needed for full wastes control stretches well beyond the closing date of the proposed project and must be continued to hold the water, solid waste and air pollution levels within efficient limits. Thlese risks are all characterized by the importance of positive government action at either the provincial or municipal level. The related institutional innovation risk was analyzed earlier. 50. Of the above risks, failure to implement agreed tariffs would seriously impair the performance incentives of the utilities and their ability to finance ongoing investment programs. To mitigate this risk, a tariff increase before negotiation is being required and tariffs will be a supervision focal point. The latter will be aided by the fact that service providers are required to present annual accounts showing whether existing tariffs have met their financial needs and to project tariff levels needed in the following year. 51. To encourage continued implementation of the broader environmental services investment program, the proposed project includes funds for further project preparation and introduces a tariff strategy that will sustain future investment. At least as important to minimizing risk in the long run program is increasing citizen attention to and demand for environmental improvements. That trend is being spurred by a special committee of the National People's Congress. While citizen awareness is not supported directly by the project, the spread of the investments is designed to provide solid evidence of the gains from pollution control and thus gamer support for further action. 52. Significant regulatory risks arise because the pollution control results anticipated for the surface waters depend not only on sewerage technologies successfully constructed and operated by the cities. Many important pollutants must be controlled at source by the industries generating them. A failure to do so could threaten either the sewerage int'rastructure or the quality of the various lakes and rivers, depending on enterprise discharge points. The principal means of mitigating this risk is a strong regulatory regime. The importance of this work was recognized during preparation of the project and is addressed under the environmental action plan (Annex I1). Risks to Long-Term Sustainability 53. The major risks to long term sustainability are financial and regulatory, and have been discussed above. Additional risks arise from outside of the cities themselves and
 -173 - ANNEX 14 center on polluting inputs to the various water bodies from areas beyond municipal control. These additional pollutants could overwhelm any benefit that would otherwise be realized by the planned investments. In the case of the network of waterways within the cities, this risk is not great. Most of their watersheds are small, pollutants are of local origin, and their control will be a function of the proper operation of the project. However, the Han and Yangtze suffer from nonpoint source pollutants, particularly agricultural, and carry substantial nutrient loads from upstream agriculture as well as industrial pollution discharges. Satisfactory abatement of those polluting sources will depend on the actions of a large number of political jurisdictions, most of which would suffer no immediate harm from continued discharges to these rivers. The growing appreciation within China of the importance of water pollution abatement offers the best hope of inducing compliance with the current industrial regulations. A similar appreciation of the risks from agriculture has yet to appear, and must become an element of river basin quality control. 54. Even if loads from other sources remain as predicted, minimizing any impact from growing municipal loads will require a high degree of municipal treatment in Xiangfan particularly. There, the Han river faces the prospect of substantial flow reductions if the South-North Water Transfer project proceeds. Even before those flows fall, the environmental assessment for this project highlighted the importance of the Han as a drinking water source and that absent early introduction of secondary treatment to Xiangfan flows, the Han would fall below the Class II status that makes it a desirable raw water source for municipal use.

doc.abstracts: The Hubei Urban Environmental Project is part of a phased development program designed to improve environmental conditions and management in Hubei Province. Specific objectives of this project are to: 1) put in place institutions and policies able to sustain progress on the provincial plan for environmental improvement; 2) improve wastewater collection and treatment in three cities, thus maintaining and raising surface water quality to levels suitable for municipal supply, agricultural, or other purposes; 3) improve wastes management in four cities, thus protecting water and land quality; and 4) identify the highest-impact industrial air and water polluters and significantly reduce their pollution. The project will support policy and institutional innovation, and provide physical works for wastewater handling, air pollution control, and solid waste management. Its components are the following: 1) Wastewater management in Huangshi, Wuhan and Xiangfan, comprising sewer systems, pump stations, and wastewater treatment facilities; 2) municipal wastes management in Huangshi, Wuhan, Xiangfan and Yichang, comprising sanitary landfill development, waste transfer facilities, vehicles and equipment; 3) industrial pollution control; 4) Hubei environmental pollution control fund; 5) water quality monitoring and management in Hubei and Wuhan environmental monitoring centers, comprising water quality monitoring technology, data management equipment, and institutional development; and 6) institutional strengthening through technical assistance and training.
